preface.title: Welcome!

blockquote.title: Mission
blockquote.para: The DocCookBook project aims to create a collection of cookbook-style solutions released under an open source license for the international DocBook community.

preface.para: DocBook is a XML format to write documentation mostly for hard- and software, but is not limited to this domain. With the help of the DocBook XSL stylesheets, text can be published into different target formats.

Although there are helpful and valuable documentation like the DocBook 5: The Definitive Guide from Norman Walsh and Bob Stayton 's DocBook XSL book, until now nobody wrote a book that combines the best of both worlds. My book is intented to be such a book. However, it does not want to replace the prior mentioned de facto standards. It aims for enhancing the world of DocBook.

My book is a collection of problem-and-solution scenarios written in a cookbook style. It is the nature of such a topic that there might be some overlap with the books above. However, it also goes beyond them to get a better and deeper understanding from the world of DocBook. I think, we benefit from different opinions and sights.

The scenarios are mostly based on my own experiences with DocBook and the DocBook XSL stylesheets. However, it also includes questions and answers from other sources: mostly the DocBook mailinglists, but also other sites that I have found. When other authors inspired me, I have included their names. If you think your name is missing, please let me know.

As I have learned a lot from the masters of DocBook, it is time to give something back. This book is written and available under a Creative Commons license. I hope the DocBook community will find it useful.

section.title: Audience
section.para: This book does not attempt to teach you DocBook or any other related technology (with the exception of ). It is targetted more for DocBook developers who seek concise examples for their problems. However, with some try-and-error it can also be useful for ordenary writers who wants to customize their documents. Readers who want further information, I have included some links in the See Also section at the end of the topic.

section.title: Further Readings
section.para: By no means is this book complete. As this book is based on technologies like CSS, XML, (X)HTML, and XSLT, it is always a good idea to seek other information. I highly recommend to read the books from Norman Walsh and Bob Stayton as mentioned above.

section.title: Feedback
section.para: The project is hosted on SourceForge under the name DocCookBook. Feel free to send me praise, constructive criticism, suggestions, ideas, improvements, or anything else. If you want to contribute to this book, I'm more than happy to give you commit rights. Send me a mail to tom_schr(AT)users.sourceforge.net.
